## Polish Peasant Farming in the Early 1900s

### Agricultural Practices and Conditions

Polish peasants in Galicia continued to use outdated agricultural techniques such as burning manure for fuel instead of using it for fertilizer, and the antiquated Medieval-era three-year crop rotation system, which had been replaced in western Poland by more modern methods. However, agricultural reforms were gradually being introduced. A number of agricultural reforms were introduced in the mid-19th century to Poland, first in German Poland, and later eastern parts of the country. The introduction of a four-crop rotation system tripled the output of Poland's farmlands.

### Land Ownership and Farm Size

The Polish peasantry faced severe challenges with land fragmentation. Most people farmed tracts of land that were too small to provide adequate sustenance for their owners. Of the total land-area in Galicia, 84.4 percent had been subdivided into farms of no more than five hectares, i.e., about twelve acres, and many were even smaller. By 1882, the average peasant holding in Galicia had declined to approximately seven acres; by 1896 the average dropped to less than six acres.

### Seasonal Work and Economic Pressures

Before the industrial revolution, peasants combined farming and nonagricultural home-based occupations, such as weaving, smithing, lace making, pottery, or tanning, producing goods to trade in their local or neighboring communities largely as a seasonal supplement to subsistence farming. Forced to seek additional employment to supplement his meager income and to meet the exorbitant land taxes, on the one hand, the peasant was confronted with few employment opportunities, on the other hand.

### Social and Economic Transformation

In the late 19th century, the beginnings of industrialization, commercial agriculture and a population boom, that exhausted available land, transformed Polish peasant-farmers into migrant-laborers. During the last quarter of the nineteenth century and the first quarter of the twentieth century, most Poles had been reduced to the status of an agricultural proletariat, or semi-proletariat. In Russian Poland, for example, 73.4 percent of the population were living in villages; in Prussian Poland, 69.3 percent; and in Austrian Poland 80.1 percent.

### Rural Life and Migration

The early 1900s marked the peak of Polish emigration, with this being the era of the Polish peasant. Between 1870 and 1914, more than 3.6 million people departed from Polish territories (of whom 2.6 million arrived in the U.S.). The Polish peasant, constituting the bulk of Polish immigration to this country, had always been agricultural. He belonged to the soil but instead, he was lured in the main into cities, factories and mines.

The search results provide a detailed picture of Polish peasant life in the early 1900s, characterized by small-scale subsistence farming, outdated agricultural techniques, severe land fragmentation, and economic pressures that drove many to seek work elsewhere or emigrate entirely.
